I am faculty working at the Information and Decision System group, Universidad de Chile, Santiago, Chile. Throughout my research career, I have been passionate about the interaction between learning and information theory. Some of my recent works have been on: universal source coding (lossy and lossless) in $\infty$-alphabets, the estimation of information measures (entropy, mutual information and divergence), learning and decision with data-rate constraints, and the characterization of nearly sparse ($\ell_p$-compressible) random sequences when relaxing stationary and ergodic assumptions.
I am currently interested in analyzing some connections between learning and information theory; learning and universal source coding; sparsity, invariance and other statistical structures that can be learned-detected from the data; as well as understanding the generalization capacity of complex learning algorithms.
I love music (the aspects of blues and jazz improvisation) and playing electric guitar.

summary: This work demonstrates a formal connection between density estimation with a data-rate constraint and the joint objective of fixed-rate universal lossy source coding and model identification.
title: Lossy Source Coding and Model Identification: Connection with Zero-Rate Density Estimation and the Skeleton Estimator

summary: This work provides new results for the analysis of random sequences in terms of $\ell_p$-compressibility.
title: Compressibility Analysis of Asymptotically Mean Stationary Processes

summary: Shannon entropy estimation in countably infinite alphabets is addressed by  adopting convergence results of the entropy functional and concentration inequalities.
title: Shannon Entropy Estimation in infinite alphabets

summary: This work introduces the notion of almost lossless source coding for infinite alphabets information sources.
title: Universal Weak Variable-Length Source Coding on Countably Infinite Alphabets

summary: This talks covers the analysis of worse-case redundancies in universal source coding in infinite alphabets.
title: Almost Lossless Universal Source Coding over Envelope Families

summary: The talk summarizes some of the research conducted at the Information and Decision System group in Astrometry.
title: Astrometry, Information Limits and Estimators

summary: This work offers a necessary and sufficient condition for a stationary and ergodic process to be  $\ell_p$-compressible.The condition reduces to check that the p-moment of the invariant distribution of the process is well defined, which contextualizes and extends the result presented by Gribonval, Cevher and Davies in 2012. Furthermore, for the scenario of non-compressible ergodic sequences, we provide a closed-form expression for the best k-term relative approximation error when only a fraction (rate) of the most significant sequence coefficients are kept as the sequence-length tends to infinity. We analyze basic properties of this rate-approximation error curve, which is again a function of the invariant measure of the process.  Revisiting the case of i.i.d. sequences, we completely identify the family of compressible processes, which reduces to look at a polynomial order decay (heavy-tail) property of the distribution.
title: On the Characterization of Compressible Ergodic Sequences

summary: A new histogram-based mutual information estimator using data-driven tree-structured partitions (TSP) is presented in this work.
title: Complexity-Regularized Tree-Structured Partition for Mutual Information Estimation

summary: This talk cover the problem of universal density estimation under an operational data-rate constraint.
title: Zero Rate Density Estimation
